Security-&-Cryptography/Whitehat,-Grey-H.content:
When Talking about hacking thereâ€™s a few different common terms that come up. These terms convey the intent, permission & motivations behind the way someone is hacking.
Legality Â§
All hacking (including white hat) can be illegal in various ways, so donâ€™t think just because you pick one of these that youâ€™re free of legal scrutiny 1 2. This changes over time, and per country, but you should look into your legal risk before doing any work on systems in particular for any situation you should:

Ask permission first before trying an exploit.

Importantly you need to get in writing that youâ€™re allowed to do what youâ€™re doing. Even if someone hires you there should be a record, or they can say they never gave you permission.


Disclose all exploits

If you come across an exploit while intentionally or unintentionally using an application you should disclose it. The two common types are responsible disclosure, and full3. Many places will have bug bounty programs exactly for this4 5


DO NOT COLLECT DATA

If you are able to get data from a system do not store it. Storing stolen data is illegal in pretty much every country, especially user data



Doing all of this does not guarantee you legal immunity, itâ€™s just the best practices to avoid most legal issues. Some countries have stronger stances on this 6 7 than others8 and that will effect legality a lot as well.
Types of Disclosures Â§
Itâ€™s important to note when disclosing bugs there are 2 main types, public/full and responsible/private. Their names should give you some indication, but essentially a full disclosure is a disclosure of a bug publicly 9 10 11. The philosophy of this is that people deserve to know their devices are vulnerable. By disclosing publicly it forces the company to resolve the issues, unlike private disclosures, which can often take years and can lead to â€catch and killâ€œ.
Private/responsible disclosures instead will report directly to the hardware/software developer directly so they can fix it without the knowledge of the public. This is often done through bug bounty programs where people are paid to find bugs. This also has the benefit of not allowing black hat hackers to use a bug while the developer is patching it.
There is a more in depth article on the ethics here.
White Hat Â§
These are typically considered the â€œgood guysâ€, the intention is to discover security vulnerabilities to help the affected systems, and importantly doing all this while they have permission to do so. White hat hackers would include people who are part of security analysis teams
Just because white hat hackers have permission does not always mean they are free from legal issues. For example a polish train service hired hackers to look into issues with a train when their warranty expired, and they are now being threatened by the manufacturer12. Likewise agents working for governments of one country do not have permission from other countries for their work, and may find themselves being charged if they enter those countries.

Grey Hat Â§
This is essentially where you are hacking â€œfor goodâ€, in a legally or ethically ambiguous way. This is someone for example who is working on a system without explicit permission. This means that you are operating in a â€œgrey-areaâ€, since you donâ€™t intend to do something wrong, but this doesnâ€™t mean you are in the clear.
Some countries will â€œupgradeâ€ grey hat hacking to white hat hacking if people follow responsible disclosure paths 6 13. These laws change by country, but in some countries it is â€œsafeâ€ to test an exploit so long as you can demonstrate itâ€™s sole purpose was to then disclose it to the company. Different countries have varying rules on this, but generally if you write up a disclosure (like a CVE) you can avoid the legal consequences. Realistically you should just go the â€œwhite hatâ€ approach first, and reach out before testing, however if you accidentally find a vulnerability in many cases you should be protected so long as you disclose it to the company that makes the software or hardware youâ€™re using.

programming/python.content:
Python is a versatile and widely-used programming language that is used by developers, data scientists, and educators alike. Created by Guido van Rossum and first released in 1991, Python has steadily grown in popularity due to its simplicity and readability. Its design philosophy emphasizes code readability, making it an ideal choice for both beginners and experienced programmers. Pythonâ€™s ease of use, combined with its robust libraries and frameworks, has made it a top choice for a wide range of applications, from web development and data analysis to artificial intelligence and scientific computing.
One of Pythonâ€™s key strengths is its extensive standard library (largely housed onÂ PyPi), which provides a wide array of modules and packages that simplify tasks such as file handling, machine learning, networking, web development and even graphical user interface (GUI) development. Pythonâ€™s versatility extends to its cross-platform compatibility, as it can be run on various operating systems, including Windows, macOS, and Linux. Furthermore, its open-source nature fosters a vibrant community of developers who continuously contribute to its growth, ensuring that Python remains at the forefront of programming languages.
Pythonâ€™s reputation as a go-to language for data science and machine learning has skyrocketed in recent years. Libraries likeÂ NumPy,Â pandas, andÂ scikit-learnÂ empower data scientists to efficiently manipulate and analyze data, while frameworks likeÂ TensorFlowÂ andÂ PyTorchÂ provide powerful tools for building and training machine learning models. LikewiseÂ Flask,Â FastAPI, andÂ DjangoÂ are web development frameworks that have become staples of modern web development. Pythonâ€™s simplicity, combined with these libraries and frameworks, has made it a driving force in the rapidly evolving fields of artificial intelligence and data-driven decision-making. In summary, Pythonâ€™s blend of simplicity, versatility, and a thriving ecosystem make it a language of choice for developers across a wide spectrum of disciplines, making it a timeless and invaluable tool in the world of programming.
CREATING AND USING FILES Â§
Creating and using Python files, also known as Python scripts, is the foundation of writing and running Python programs. Hereâ€™s a beginner-friendly explanation of how to get started:
INSTALLING PYTHON Â§

Before you start creating Python files, you need to have Python installed on your computer. You can download it from the official Python website (https://www.python.org/downloads/).
Follow the installation instructions for your operating system.

EDITING PYTHON CODE Â§

You can write Python code using a simple text editor (like Notepad on Windows or TextEdit on macOS) or use specialized Python IDEs (Integrated Development Environments) like Visual Studio Code, PyCharm, or IDLE.
Choose the option that suits you best. IDEs provide additional features to make coding easier.

CREATING A PYTHON FILE Â§

In your chosen text editor or IDE, create a new file. To do this, go to â€œFileâ€ > â€œNewâ€ or pressÂ Ctrl+NÂ (Windows) orÂ Cmd+NÂ (macOS).
Save the file with aÂ .pyÂ extension, which indicates itâ€™s a Python script. For example, you can save it asÂ my_script.py.

WRITING YOUR FIRST PYTHON CODE Â§

In your newly created Python file, you can start writing Python code. Hereâ€™s a simple â€œHello, World!â€ example:

print("Hello, World!")

This code uses theÂ print()Â function to display â€œHello, World!â€ on the screen.

RUNNING YOUR PYTHON SCRIPT Â§

To run your Python script, you need to open a terminal or command prompt.
Navigate to the directory where your Python file is located using theÂ cdÂ command (e.g.,Â cd DocumentsÂ if your file is in the â€œDocumentsâ€ folder).
Then, typeÂ pythonÂ followed by the name of your Python file and press Enter:

python my_script.py

Your Python script will execute, and youâ€™ll see the output in the terminal.

EDITING AND SAVING CHANGES Â§

You can make changes to your Python file by opening it in your text editor or IDE, editing the code, and saving the file (usually by pressingÂ Ctrl+SÂ orÂ Cmd+S).
After saving, you can rerun the script to see the updated results.

LEARNING AND EXPERIMENTING Â§

Python is a versatile language with many features and libraries. You can learn by exploring Python tutorials, books, or online courses.
As you learn, you can create more complex Python scripts to perform various tasks, from simple calculations to building web applications or analyzing data.

Thatâ€™s the basic process of creating and using Python files. Start with simple scripts like â€œHello, World!â€ and gradually build your skills by tackling more advanced projects. Python is known for its readability and simplicity, making it an excellent choice for beginners to start their coding journey.
VARIABLES & TYPES Â§
Python is a versatile programming language that can work with various types of data. Hereâ€™s a basic overview of three fundamental data types:Â int,Â float, andÂ str. These 3 data types help to make up most of the basic operations you will do.
INTEGERS (INT) Â§
Integers are whole numbers, which means they donâ€™t have any decimal points.

You can use integers for counting, indexing, and performing arithmetic operations like addition and subtraction.
For Example:Â 5,Â -10,Â 1000

my_integer = 42print(my_integer)  # Output: 42
FLOATING-POINT NUMBERS (FLOAT) Â§

Floating-point numbers, or floats, are numbers that can have decimal points.
You use floats when you need to represent values with precision, such as measurements or calculations involving fractions.
Example:Â 3.14,Â -0.5,Â 2.0

my_float = 3.14159print(my_float)  # Output: 3.14159
STRINGS (STR) Â§

Strings are sequences of characters, like text or words, enclosed in single (â€™ â€˜), double (â€ â€œ), or triple (â€™â€™â€™ â€™â€™â€™ or â€â€â€ â€œâ€â€) quotes.
You can manipulate strings, concatenate them (combine them), and perform various operations like searching for specific characters.
Example:Â 'Hello, World!',Â "Python is fun",Â '''Triple-quoted strings'''

my_string = "Hello, World!"print(my_string)  # Output: Hello, World!
These three basic data types are the building blocks for most Python programs. You can perform operations on them, combine them, and use them to represent different kinds of data in your code. As you continue to learn Python, youâ€™ll discover more data types and ways to work with them, but these are the essential ones to get started.
COLLECTIONS Â§
If you are not familiar you can find details about what collections areÂ here.
Python provides two common collection types, lists, and tuples. These collection types allow you to store multiple values in a single variable.
Lists Â§

A list is an ordered collection of items.
You can store various types of data in a list, such as numbers, strings, or even other lists.
Lists are mutable, which means you can change their contents (add, remove, or modify elements).

Creating a List:Â To create a list, use square bracketsÂ []Â and separate the items with commas.
my_list = [1, 2, 3, "apple", "banana"]
Accessing Elements:Â You can access individual elements in a list by their position, called an index. Python uses zero-based indexing, so the first element is at index 0.
first_item = my_list[0]  # Gets the first item (1)second_item = my_list[1]  # Gets the second item (2)
Modifying a List:Â You can change, add, or remove items from a list.
my_list[3] = "cherry"  # Modifies an item (changes "apple" to "cherry")my_list.append(4)  # Adds an item to the end (appends 4)my_list.remove("banana")  # Removes an item (removes "banana")
Tuples Â§

A tuple is similar to a list, but it is immutable, meaning you cannot change its elements once itâ€™s created.
Tuples are typically used when you want to create a collection of items that should not be modified.

Creating a Tuple:Â To create a tuple, use parenthesesÂ ()Â and separate the items with commas.
my_tuple = (1, 2, 3, "apple", "banana")
Accessing Elements:Â You access tuple elements in the same way as with lists, using zero-based indexing.
first_item = my_tuple[0]  # Gets the first item (1)second_item = my_tuple[1]  # Gets the second item (2)
Immutable Nature:Â You cannot change the elements of a tuple after creation. Attempting to do so will result in an error.
my_tuple[3] = "cherry"  # This will raise an error (Tuples are immutable)
When to Use Lists vs. Tuples:

Use lists when you need a collection of items that can change over time.
Use tuples when you want to create a collection of items that should remain constant.

Hereâ€™s a simple summary: Lists are like dynamic containers where you can put different things and change them, while tuples are like sealed containers where you put things that wonâ€™t change. Both are valuable tools in Python, and your choice depends on your specific needs in a program.
FUNCTIONS Â§
If you are not familiar you can find details about what functions areÂ here.
Python functions are like mini-programs or reusable blocks of code that perform specific tasks. Think of them as functions in math, where you input something, and it gives you a result. In Python, you can create your own functions to perform tasks you need. Hereâ€™s a beginner-friendly explanation:
DEFINING A FUNCTION Â§

To create a function, you use theÂ defÂ keyword, followed by the function name and parenthesesÂ (). You can also include parameters (input values) inside the parentheses.

def greet(name):    print("Hello, " + name + "!")

In this example, we defined a function calledÂ greetÂ that takes one parameter,Â name.

CALLING A FUNCTION Â§

Once youâ€™ve defined a function, you can use it by calling it. To call a function, you simply write its name followed by parentheses and any necessary arguments (values for the parameters).

greet("Alice")

This line of code calls theÂ greetÂ function and passesÂ "Alice"Â as theÂ nameÂ parameter.

RETURN VALUES Â§

Functions can also return a result using theÂ returnÂ keyword. This is like the answer you get from a math function.

def add(a, b):    result = a + b    return result

In this example, theÂ addÂ function takes two parameters,Â aÂ andÂ b, adds them together, and returns the result.

sum_result = add(5, 3)print(sum_result)  # Output: 8

Here, we call theÂ addÂ function withÂ 5Â andÂ 3Â as arguments and store the result in theÂ sum_resultÂ variable.

REUSABILITY Â§

Functions make your code more organized and reusable. You can use the same function multiple times throughout your program.

SCOPE Â§

Variables defined inside a function have local scope, meaning they can only be accessed within that function. Variables outside the function have global scope, which means they can be used throughout your code.

BUILT-IN FUNCTIONS Â§

Python also comes with many built-in functions, likeÂ print(),Â len(), andÂ input(), which you can use without having to define them yourself.

Hereâ€™s a simple summary: Functions in Python allow you to define a set of instructions that can be used over and over again. They take input, perform actions, and can return results. Functions are like handy tools you create to make your coding tasks easier and more organized.
CONTROL FLOWS Â§
Python control flows, especially theÂ ifÂ statement, help you make decisions in your code. Think of them as instructions to your program to perform certain actions based on conditions. Letâ€™s break it down in a beginner-friendly way:
THEÂ IFÂ STATEMENT Â§

TheÂ ifÂ statement is used to make decisions in Python.
It allows your program to execute different code blocks depending on whether a condition is true or false.

BASICÂ IFÂ SYNTAX Â§

The basic structure of anÂ ifÂ statement looks like this:

if condition:    # Code to execute if the condition is True

TheÂ conditionÂ is an expression that evaluates to eitherÂ TrueÂ orÂ False.

TRUTHINESS Â§

In Python, many things can be considered either â€œtruthyâ€ or â€œfalsy.â€ This means that they can be evaluated as equivalent toÂ TrueÂ orÂ FalseÂ in a boolean context.
Common truthy values include non-zero numbers, non-empty strings, and non-empty containers (like lists or dictionaries).
Common falsy values includeÂ 0, an empty stringÂ "", and empty containers.

BOOLEAN LOGICAL COMPARISONS Â§


You can compare values using boolean logical operators to create conditions in yourÂ ifÂ statements.


Common boolean operators are:

==Â (equal): Checks if two values are equal.
!=Â (not equal): Checks if two values are not equal.
<Â (less than): Checks if one value is less than another.
>Â (greater than): Checks if one value is greater than another.
<=Â (less than or equal to): Checks if one value is less than or equal to another.
>=Â (greater than or equal to): Checks if one value is greater than or equal to another.



Example:
x = 5y = 10 if x < y:    print("x is less than y")

In this example, theÂ ifÂ statement checks ifÂ xÂ is less thanÂ y. If itâ€™s true, it prints â€œx is less than y.â€

ELSEÂ ANDÂ ELIFÂ (ELSE-IF) STATEMENTS Â§

You can extendÂ ifÂ statements withÂ elseÂ andÂ elifÂ (else-if) statements to handle multiple conditions.

Example:
age = 20 if age < 18:    print("You are underage.")elif age >= 18 and age < 65:    print("You are an adult.")else:    print("You are a senior citizen.")

In this example, the code checks different conditions based on the age variable and prints an appropriate message.

NESTEDÂ IFÂ STATEMENTS Â§

You can also nestÂ ifÂ statements inside otherÂ ifÂ statements to handle more complex conditions.

Example:
x = 5 if x > 0:    if x % 2 == 0:        print("x is a positive even number.")    else:        print("x is a positive odd number.")else:    print("x is not a positive number.")

In this example, we have nestedÂ ifÂ statements to determine whetherÂ xÂ is positive and even or positive and odd.

In summary,Â ifÂ statements allow your Python program to make decisions based on conditions. You can use boolean operators to create conditions, and you can includeÂ elseÂ andÂ elifÂ statements for more complex decision-making. This is a fundamental building block for creating dynamic and responsive code in Python.
LOOPS Â§
Python loops are used to repeatedly execute a block of code. They allow you to automate repetitive tasks by running the same code multiple times. Letâ€™s explore Python loops in a beginner-friendly way:
TheÂ forÂ Loop Â§

AÂ forÂ loop is used when you know how many times you want to repeat a certain action. Itâ€™s often used to iterate over a sequence, such as a list or a range of numbers.

BasicÂ forÂ Loop Syntax:
for variable in sequence:    # Code to execute in each iteration

variableÂ represents an item from the sequence in each iteration, andÂ sequenceÂ is the collection of items to loop through.

Example:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"] for fruit in fruits:    print(fruit)

In this example, theÂ forÂ loop iterates through theÂ fruitsÂ list and prints each fruit one by one.

TheÂ whileÂ Loop Â§

AÂ whileÂ loop is used when you want to repeat a block of code as long as a certain condition is true. Itâ€™s often used when you donâ€™t know in advance how many times the loop will run.

BasicÂ whileÂ Loop Syntax:
while condition:    # Code to execute as long as the condition is True

The loop will continue running as long asÂ conditionÂ remainsÂ True.

Example:
count = 0 while count < 5:    print("Count: ", count)    count += 1

In this example, theÂ whileÂ loop prints the value ofÂ countÂ as long as itâ€™s less thanÂ 5, incrementingÂ countÂ in each iteration.

Loop Control Statements Â§

You can control the flow of loops using special statements:

break: Terminates the loop prematurely.
continue: Skips the current iteration and moves to the next.



Example (usingÂ break):
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6] for num in numbers:    if num == 4:        break  # Exit the loop when num is 4    print(num)

In this example, the loop stops whenÂ numÂ becomesÂ 4, and the code after the loop continues executing.

Example (usingÂ continue):
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6] for num in numbers:    if num % 2 == 0:        continue  # Skip even numbers    print(num)

In this example, the loop skips even numbers and continues to the next iteration.

Python loops are powerful tools for automating repetitive tasks and processing data. By understandingÂ forÂ andÂ whileÂ loops and how to control their flow, you can make your programs more dynamic and efficient.
DEFINING YOUR OWN TYPES Â§
In Python, classes are like blueprints for creating objects. Think of a class as a template that defines the properties (attributes) and behaviors (methods) that objects of that class will have. Letâ€™s break down Python classes in a beginner-friendly way:
CLASS DEFINITION Â§

To create a class, you use theÂ classÂ keyword, followed by the name of the class (usually starting with a capital letter).

class Dog:    # Class definition goes here

In this example, weâ€™ve defined a class calledÂ Dog.

ATTRIBUTES Â§

Attributes are variables that store data within a class. They represent the characteristics or properties of objects created from the class.

class Dog:    breed = "Unknown"  # Attribute to store the dog's breed    age = 0           # Attribute to store the dog's age

In this class,Â breedÂ andÂ ageÂ are attributes that every dog object will have.

METHODS Â§

Methods are functions defined within a class. They represent the actions or behaviors that objects of the class can perform.

class Dog:    breed = "Unknown"    age = 0     def bark(self):        print("Woof! Woof!")     def fetch(self):        print("Fetching the ball...")

In this class,Â bark()Â andÂ fetch()Â are methods that represent the actions a dog can do.

CREATING OBJECTS (INSTANCES) Â§

To use a class, you create objects (instances) from it. An object is a specific instance of a class.

my_dog = Dog()  # Creating an instance of the Dog class

my_dogÂ is now an object of theÂ DogÂ class.

ACCESSING ATTRIBUTES AND METHODS Â§

You can access attributes and methods of an object using dot notation (object_name.attributeÂ orÂ object_name.method()).

my_dog.breed = "Golden Retriever"  # Setting the breed attributemy_dog.age = 3                    # Setting the age attribute print("My dog is a", my_dog.breed)  # Accessing the breed attributemy_dog.bark()                       # Calling the bark method

Here, weâ€™ve set theÂ breedÂ andÂ ageÂ attributes and called theÂ bark()Â method onÂ my_dog.

CONSTRUCTOR METHOD (__INIT__) Â§

TheÂ __init__Â method is a special method in Python classes. Itâ€™s called when you create an object from the class and is used to initialize attributes.

class Dog:    def __init__(self, breed, age):        self.breed = breed        self.age = age     def bark(self):        print("Woof! Woof!")

When you create aÂ DogÂ object, you need to provide values forÂ breedÂ andÂ age.

my_dog = Dog("Golden Retriever", 3)

This way, you can create a dog object with specific attributes during its creation.

Thatâ€™s the basic idea of Python classes! Classes allow you to define a blueprint for creating objects with specific attributes and behaviors. They help you organize your code in a structured and reusable way, which is especially useful for building complex applications.
Type hints Â§
Type hints are a way in python to specify the intended type of a variable (not enforced just highly suggested). This works by having a colon, then the type declaration for each varaible/parameter/attribute.
